articles.title: Alzheimer's finger-prick blood test could transform diagnosis, experts say
articles.summary: An international trial involving 1,000 volunteers will aim to detect biomarkers associated with the condition.
articles.content:
Alzheimer's finger-prick test could help diagnosis

5 hours ago Share Save Fergus Walsh Medical editor Share Save

BBC Dr Michael Sandberg, whose mother had Alzheimer's disease, took part in the trial

An international trial is examining whether a finger-prick blood test could be used to help diagnose Alzheimer's disease. The study, involving 1,000 volunteers aged over 60 in the UK, US and Canada, will aim to detect biomarkers associated with the condition. Dr Michael Sandberg, a London GP, was encouraged to take part in the study after witnessing his mother's slow decline from Alzheimer's disease. He had a negative result from the tests and said it was "a huge relief". The Bio-Hermes-002 study is led by the medical research charity LifeArc and the Global Alzheimer's Platform Foundation, with support from the UK Dementia Research Institute.

Dr Giovanna Lalli, director of strategy and operations at LifeArc, said: "We are looking at the presence of three proteins that have been linked to Alzheimer's disease, so-called blood-based biomarkers. "By analysing the concentration and the levels of these proteins it may tell us whether a person is at risk of developing Alzheimer's disease." Studies have shown that rogue proteins called amyloid and tau can accumulate in the brains of individuals over 15 years before they start to display symptoms of Alzheimer's, the most common form of dementia.

The finger-prick test could be done at home in the future

All the volunteers will have the current gold-standard tests for Alzheimer's which involve a specialised brain PET scan using a radioactive tracer, or a lumbar puncture to remove a sample of cerebrospinal fluid. Such tests are expensive, time-consuming and invasive and only two in 100 Alzheimer's patients are offered them, so the hope is that the finger-prick test could help revolutionise how the disease is identified.

Prof Fiona Carragher, chief policy and research officer at the Alzheimer's Society, said, with tests not currently widely available across the UK, "getting an accurate diagnosis takes far too long". She added: "With new treatments on the horizon, early and accurate diagnosis must be a priority for the NHS. That's why we're funding work to bring blood tests for dementia to the NHS, so everyone who would benefit from a diagnosis can get one quickly and accurately."

Dr Giovanna Lalli, from LifeArc, says her team are looking at the presence of three proteins in the blood that have been linked to Alzheimer's

Trial participant Sandberg told the BBC: "My mother did very well on a trial and that encouraged me to take part. "I believe knowledge is power and am really excited that you may be able to screen people at risk of dementia without expensive scans or needles." When Sandberg was given his results, both the brain scan and the finger-prick test were negative. He said: "It's a huge relief, knowing what my mother went through". This is - of course - just one set of results. Scientists will need to analyse the findings from all 1,000 volunteers on the trial before they know how useful the finger-prick blood test is at spotting the risk of Alzheimer's.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on an international clinical trial testing a finger-prick blood test to detect Alzheimer's disease biomarkers, which could revolutionize early diagnosis by providing a less invasive, more accessible, and cost-effective alternative to current methods. This has broad significance for millions at risk of Alzheimer's worldwide, offering hope for earlier intervention and better outcomes. The article provides sufficient detail about the trial, its scope, and potential impact, making it a substantive and inspiring health breakthrough.

articles.title: Scientists sent viruses to space and they evolved in surprising ways
articles.summary: When scientists sent bacteria-infecting viruses to the International Space Station, the microbes did not behave the same way they do on Earth. In microgravity, infections still occurred, but both viruses and bacteria evolved differently over time. Genetic changes emerged that altered how viruses attach to bacteria and how bacteria defend themselves. The findings could help improve phage therapies against drug-resistant infections.
articles.content:
In a new study, terrestrial bacteria-infecting viruses were still able to infect their E. coli hosts in near-weightless "microgravity" conditions aboard the International Space Station, but the dynamics of virus-bacteria interactions differed from those observed on Earth. Phil Huss of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, U.S.A., and colleagues present these findings January 13thin the open-access journal PLOS Biology.

Interactions between phages -- viruses that infect bacteria -- and their hosts play an integral role in microbial ecosystems. Often described as being in an evolutionary "arms race," bacteria can evolve defenses against phages, while phages develop new ways to thwart defenses. While virus-bacteria interactions have been studied extensively on Earth, microgravity conditions alter bacterial physiology and the physics of virus-bacteria collisions, disrupting typical interactions.

However, few studies have explored the specifics of how phage-bacteria dynamics differ in microgravity. To address that gap, Huss and colleagues compared two sets of bacterial E. coli samples infected with a phage known as T7 -- one set incubated on Earth and the other aboard the International Space Station.

Analysis of the space-station samples showed that, after an initial delay, the T7 phage successfully infected the E. coli. However, whole-genome sequencing revealed marked differences in both bacterial and viral genetic mutations between the Earth samples versus the microgravity samples.

The space-station phages gradually accumulated specific mutations that could boost phage infectivity or their ability to bind receptors on bacterial cells. Meanwhile, the space-station E. coli accumulated mutations that could protect against phages and enhance survival success in near-weightless conditions.

The researchers then applied a high-throughput technique known as deep mutational scanning to more closely examine changes in the T7 receptor binding protein, which plays a key role in infection, revealing further significant differences between microgravity versus Earth conditions. Additional experiments on Earth linked these microgravity-associated changes in the receptor binding protein to increased activity against E. coli strains that cause urinary tract infections in humans and are normally resistant to T7.

Overall, this study highlights the potential for phage research aboard the ISS to reveal new insights into microbial adaption, with potential relevance to both space exploration and human health.

The authors add, "Space fundamentally changes how phages and bacteria interact: infection is slowed, and both organisms evolve along a different trajectory than they do on Earth. By studying those space-driven adaptations, we identified new biological insights that allowed us to engineer phages with far superior activity against drug-resistant pathogens back on Earth."

In your coverage, please use this URL to provide access to the freely available paper in PLOS Biology: https://plos.io/4q4S9AO

Citation: Huss P, Chitboonthavisuk C, Meger A, Nishikawa K, Oates RP, Mills H, et al. (2026) Microgravity reshapes bacteriophage-host coevolution aboard the International Space Station. PLoS Biol 24(1): e3003568. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3003568

Author countries: United StatesFunding: This work was supported by the Defense Threat Reduction Agency (https://www.dtra.mil/) (Grant HDTRA1-16-1-0049) to S.R. C.C. was supported by a graduate training scholarship from the Anandamahidol Foundation (Thailand). The sponsors or funders did not play any role in the study design, data collection and analysis, decision to publish, or preparation of the manuscript.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about how viruses and bacteria evolve differently in microgravity, with practical implications for improving phage therapies against drug-resistant infections. This breakthrough has broad relevance for human health and space exploration, providing new insights that could lead to better treatments for antibiotic-resistant infections on Earth.
articles.personality_title: Viruses and bacteria evolve differently in space, offering new clues for fighting infections
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study how viruses that infect bacteria, called phages, interact with their hosts on Earth. These interactions are important because bacteria and phages constantly change to fight each other. But little is known about how this works in space, where gravity is much weaker.

**What happened** – Researchers sent bacteria and phages to the International Space Station (ISS) to see how they behave in microgravity. They infected E. coli bacteria with a virus called T7 both on Earth and in space. After some time, they found that the viruses and bacteria in space changed their genes differently than those on Earth. The viruses evolved to better attach to bacteria, while the bacteria developed stronger defenses.

**Impact** – This is important because it shows that space conditions change how viruses and bacteria evolve. The study also found that these space-evolved viruses could better fight certain bacteria that cause infections in humans and are usually resistant to treatments. This discovery could help scientists create new therapies to treat drug-resistant infections on Earth.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to continue studying how space affects microbes to learn more about their evolution. This research could lead to improved phage therapies for infections and help protect astronauts from bacteria during long space missions.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Sending viruses and bacteria to space reveals new ways they evolve, which could help develop better treatments for infections resistant to antibiotics.

articles.title: A 47-year study reveals when fitness and strength start to fade
articles.summary: A long-running Swedish study has followed adults for nearly five decades, uncovering when physical decline truly begins. Fitness and strength start slipping around age 35, then worsen gradually with age. The encouraging twist: adults who began exercising later still improved their physical capacity by up to 10 percent. It’s a powerful reminder that staying active matters, even if you start late.
articles.content:
A long-running Swedish study conducted at Karolinska Institutet has followed people for 47 years to examine how fitness, strength, and muscle endurance evolve during adulthood. The findings show that physical performance begins to decline around age 35. At the same time, the research makes it clear that starting to exercise later in life can still bring meaningful benefits.

The research is part of the Swedish Physical Activity and Fitness study (SPAF), which tracked several hundred randomly selected men and women between the ages of 16 and 63. Published in the Journal of Cachexia, Sarcopenia and Muscle, the study offers rare long-term insight into how physical capacity changes over decades rather than snapshots at a single point in time.

Most earlier research in this area relied on cross-sectional data, comparing different age groups rather than following the same individuals. In contrast, the SPAF study repeatedly measured fitness and strength in the same participants across Sweden for nearly half a century, making it one of the most comprehensive efforts of its kind.

Fitness Declines After 35 but Activity Still Helps

The results show that both fitness and strength start to decrease as early as age 35, regardless of how much people trained earlier in life. From that point forward, physical decline continues gradually and tends to speed up with advancing age. Despite this pattern, the researchers found encouraging evidence that exercise remains valuable at any stage. Participants who became physically active during adulthood increased their physical capacity by 5-10 percent.

"It is never too late to start moving. Our study shows that physical activity can slow the decline in performance, even if it cannot completely stop it. Now we will look for the mechanisms behind why everyone reaches their peak performance at age 35 and why physical activity can slow performance loss but not completely halt it," says Maria Westerståhl, lecturer at the Department of Laboratory Medicine and lead author of the study.

What Comes Next for the Study

The research is ongoing. Next year, the participants will be examined again when they reach age 68. The team hopes to better understand how changes in physical performance are connected to lifestyle choices, overall health, and underlying biological processes.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant long-term scientific study revealing when physical decline begins and highlights that starting exercise later in life still yields meaningful health benefits. This has broad public health implications by encouraging physical activity at any age, supported by robust longitudinal data.
articles.personality_title: Study shows fitness starts to decline at 35 but exercise helps at any age
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – A Swedish research project has tracked the same people for 47 years to see how fitness and strength change as adults get older. Unlike many studies that only look at different age groups once, this one followed individuals over a long time.

**What happened** – The Swedish Physical Activity and Fitness study (SPAF) measured fitness, strength, and muscle endurance in men and women aged 16 to 63. It found that physical abilities begin to decline around age 35 and gradually worsen with age. However, adults who started exercising later still improved their fitness by up to 10 percent.

**Impact** – This study is important because it shows that physical decline starts earlier than many might think, but also that it is never too late to benefit from exercise. Even people who begin being active later in life can slow down the loss of strength and endurance.

**What's next step** – Researchers will continue to study the participants, checking their fitness again at age 68. They want to learn how lifestyle and health affect physical decline and why exercise helps slow it down.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Fitness and strength start to fade around age 35, but starting to exercise at any age can still improve physical ability.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une étude révèle que la forme décline à partir de 35 ans mais l’exercice aide à tout âge
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Un projet de recherche suédois a suivi les mêmes personnes pendant 47 ans pour observer comment la forme physique et la force évoluent avec l’âge. Contrairement à beaucoup d’études qui comparent seulement différents groupes d’âge une fois, celle-ci a suivi des individus sur une longue période.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’étude suédoise sur l’activité physique et la forme (SPAF) a mesuré la forme, la force et l’endurance musculaire chez des hommes et femmes de 16 à 63 ans. Elle a montré que les capacités physiques commencent à décliner vers 35 ans et s’aggravent progressivement avec l’âge. Mais les adultes qui se sont mis à faire de l’exercice plus tard ont quand même amélioré leur forme jusqu’à 10 %.

**Impact** – Cette étude est importante car elle montre que le déclin physique débute plus tôt qu’on ne le pense souvent, mais aussi qu’il n’est jamais trop tard pour profiter des bienfaits de l’exercice. Même les personnes actives tardivement peuvent ralentir la perte de force et d’endurance.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs continueront à étudier les participants, en mesurant leur forme à 68 ans. Ils veulent comprendre comment le mode de vie et la santé influencent ce déclin et pourquoi l’exercice aide à le ralentir.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La forme et la force commencent à diminuer vers 35 ans, mais se mettre à faire de l’exercice à tout âge peut améliorer les capacités physiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Estudio muestra que la forma física comienza a declinar a los 35 años pero el ejercicio ayuda a cualquier edad
articles.personality_presentation_es:

articles.reasoning: The article reports on evidence that the HPV vaccine not only protects vaccinated individuals but also provides a herd immunity effect that reduces precancerous growths in unvaccinated women, indicating a broad public health benefit in preventing cervical cancer.
articles.personality_title: HPV vaccine helps protect even those who don’t get the shot
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a common virus that can cause cervical cancer in women. Vaccines have been developed to protect people from HPV and reduce cervical cancer risk.

**What happened** – A recent study published in January 2026 found that women who did not receive the HPV vaccine showed fewer precancerous growths. This suggests that the vaccine is creating a 'herd effect,' meaning it helps protect people who haven’t been vaccinated.

**Impact** – This is important because it shows the vaccine’s benefits go beyond just the individuals who get the shot. When enough people are vaccinated, the virus spreads less, making it safer for everyone. This can help reduce cervical cancer rates more widely.

**What's next step** – Researchers and health officials will likely continue to encourage HPV vaccination and study how this herd effect can be strengthened. This could lead to better vaccination programs and fewer cervical cancer cases in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The HPV vaccine not only protects those vaccinated but also helps reduce cancer risk for unvaccinated women through a herd immunity effect.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le vaccin contre le HPV protège aussi les non-vaccinées
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le papillomavirus humain (HPV) est un virus courant qui peut causer le cancer du col de l’utérus chez les femmes. Des vaccins ont été créés pour protéger contre le HPV et réduire ce risque.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une étude récente publiée en janvier 2026 a montré que les femmes non vaccinées avaient moins de lésions précancéreuses. Cela suggère que le vaccin crée un « effet de groupe », protégeant aussi celles qui ne sont pas vaccinées.

**Impact** – C’est important car cela montre que le vaccin aide plus que les personnes qui le reçoivent. Quand beaucoup sont vaccinées, le virus se propage moins, ce qui protège tout le monde et peut réduire le cancer du col.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs et responsables de santé vont encourager la vaccination et étudier comment renforcer cet effet de groupe. Cela pourrait améliorer les programmes de vaccination et diminuer les cas de cancer.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le vaccin contre le HPV protège les vaccinées et réduit aussi le risque de cancer chez les non-vaccinées grâce à un effet d’immunité collective.
articles.personality_title_es: La vacuna contra el VPH protege también a quienes no se vacunan
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El virus del papiloma humano (VPH) es común y puede causar cáncer de cuello uterino en mujeres. Se han creado vacunas para proteger contra el VPH y reducir este riesgo.
